title: 110_hr2399
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alien Smuggling and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007". Congress finds that alien smuggling is a transnational crime that violates US borders, compromises sovereignty, and poses a risk of terrorist activity. Aggressive enforcement is needed to protect the nation, with recognition for the efforts of border security agencies and law enforcement. The law enforcement community needs stronger statutory tools to address the security threat of alien smuggling. Existing penalties are inadequate to punish smugglers effectively, and current laws often do not reach all individuals involved in smuggling activities. Alien smuggling destabilizes border communities, requiring collaboration among various agencies and organizations to combat and respond to its effects. Alien smuggling involves reckless transportation of individuals on the high seas, often conducted outside the United States. Extraterritorial jurisdiction is necessary to hold smuggling rings accountable for their actions. Smuggling can also lead to unsafe conditions, putting individuals at high risk of injury or death. The Department of Homeland Security will check alien smugglers and smuggled individuals against terrorist watchlists at U.S. borders. Additionally, there will be stronger prosecution and punishment for alien smugglers. Section 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens. This includes bringing individuals to the United States without lawful authority and recruiting or encouraging them to enter or reside in the country. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens, including bringing individuals to the United States without lawful authority, transporting them within the country, harboring them, or attempting to do so. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens. Violators may be fined or imprisoned for up to 5 years. If the offense involves a family member and is not for profit, the penalty is up to 1 year. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address the smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens. Violators may be fined or imprisoned for up to 5 years. If the offense involves profit, commercial advantage, or private financial gain, the penalty is imprisonment for not more than 10 years, or both. If the offense results in serious bodily injury, the penalty is imprisonment for not less than 5 nor more than 15 years. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens. Penalties include fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. Offenses involving profit or serious bodily injury may result in imprisonment for up to 10 or 15 years respectively. Offenses related to terrorist activity can lead to imprisonment for up to 30 years. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to address smuggling of unlawful and terrorist aliens, with penalties including fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. Offenses involving profit or serious bodily injury may result in imprisonment for up to 10 or 15 years respectively. Offenses related to terrorist activity can lead to imprisonment for up to 30 years. Additionally, there is extraterritorial jurisdiction over certain offenses described in the Act. In a prosecution for smuggling on the high seas, no defense of necessity can be raised unless the defendant reports to the Coast Guard and does not facilitate illegal entry of aliens into the US without lawful authority. It is a defense for a religious organization to enable an alien to work as a volunteer minister or missionary in the US without compensation, as long as basic living expenses are provided, and the individual has been a member of the organization for at least one year. For a religious organization, allowing an alien to work as a volunteer minister or missionary in the US without pay is permitted if basic living expenses are covered, and the individual has been a member of the denomination for at least a year. The terms 'United States' and 'lawful authority' are defined in relation to immigration laws. SEC. 5. MARITIME LAW ENFORCEMENT. Penalties for intentionally violating section 2237 of title 18, United States Code include fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. If the offense is related to specific crimes, the offender may face a fine or imprisonment for up to 10 years. The penalties for violating section 2237 of title 18, United States Code include fines, imprisonment for up to 15 years, or both, depending on the severity of the offense. In a prosecution for a violation of this section, no defense based on necessity can be raised unless the defendant delivered the person to emergency personnel, reported to the Coast Guard, and did not bring any alien into the US without lawful authority. In cases where an alien's life is in danger, the reporting requirement can be fulfilled by notifying the Coast Guard after delivering the person to emergency personnel ashore. The term 'transportation under inhumane conditions' includes transporting persons in confined spaces, at excessive speeds, or exceeding the rated capacity of the means of transportation. The term 'transportation under inhumane conditions' includes exceeding the rated capacity of the means of transportation or intentionally grounding a vessel with persons on board. SEC. 6. AMENDMENT TO THE SENTENCING GUIDELINES. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling offenses and obstruction of boarding. Considerations include enhancements for repeated violations, involvement in organized enterprises, and transportation of groups of 10 or more aliens. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for alien smuggling offenses, including enhancements for repeated violations, organized enterprises, and transportation of groups of 10 or more aliens. The guidelines may also consider cross-references to Criminal Sexual Abuse and Attempted Murder. Expedited procedures may be used for promulgating guidelines or amendments. Section 21(a) of the Sentencing Act of 1987 is extended as if the authority had not expired.
